Finally, I sometimes think we pretend we have magic wands wrt PA. And it is kind of magic—mostly are wildly inactive, and need to fix that first—but it is also important to think about the manipulable markers of declining fitness with age, and focus, at least in part, on those.

And, of course, as my friend @hjluks has beaten into my head, sarcopenia is deadly. Given the choice between cardiovascular fitness and doing resistance training as you get older, err on the side of the latter, within reason.

Similarly, stroke volume is indirectly manipulable. You can improve contractility, lessen arterial stiffness, and so on, even if your maximum heart-rate declines with age. This will improve stroke volume, or at least lessen its decline.

But there are things to do. Mitochondrial dysfunction, for example, is associated with metabolic disease, and that is  avoidable, in large part. I'm always interested in studies that compare high/low PA groups the extent to which the high PA group already has metabolic disease.

Only a few of these are in any way manipulable. And, worse, there is immense survivor bias, with studies among aging cohorts limited to studying those who can be active—that is, without comorbidities that prevent them from being active enough to slow the rate of fitness decline.

There are many, many things associated with declining age-related fitness decline. even among the active. A partial list:
- Declining heart stroke volume
- Mitochondrial dysfunction
- Poor skeletal muscle oxygenation
- Declining vo2max (10% per decade after 30-ish)
- Sarcopenia
